revised_title: Cell Size and Number Contributions to Organ and Body Size Evolution in Hawaiian Drosophila
tldr: The study examines organ and cell allometry in Hawaiian Drosophila species with varying body lengths. It finds that cell size contributes between one-third and two-thirds to evolutionary changes in organ and body size, challenging the textbook answer that larger organisms result from an increase in cell number and not cell size. The research also provides insights into the developmental programs that produce individuals and organs of different sizes.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Developmental Biology
